discourse_list.title: Discussion: Why are people so afraid of unbacked Dai?

content.content: Printing unbacked dai would allow maker to benefit tremendously from the current demand for Dai.  We could use the unbacked Dai to buy and burn MKR, for example, or to pay for much needed dev support to accelerate protocol improvements.  Furthermore, printing unbacked Dai would help fix the peg without taking on the protocol risk of massive amounts of centralized stablecoins -not just through selling the Dai but also lowering the collateral backing to say $0.99 from current $1.00. People buying Dai now are essentially buying unbacked dai - as they pay $1.03 for something backed by $1.00 in collateral. Some people may worry that the Dai price would crash- but this can be managed by limiting the amount.  In reality it would just help us restore the peg.   Once the peg is restored, we could use the SF income to burn the unbacked Dai before we start burning MKR again. Printing unbacked Dai when Dai is above its peg and selling the Dai to burn MKR is effectively just borrowing from future MKR burns when the SF income is high - but this would allow much better peg management and avoid risks and negative PR of taking on massive amounts of USDC to fix the peg. It would allow us to have a smooth rate of MKR burn whereas now we essentially have zero and in some future time we hope it will be restored.
content.GPT-summary: The author proposes printing unbacked Dai to benefit from the current demand for Dai and fix the peg without taking on the protocol risk of centralized stablecoins. The proposal suggests using the unbacked Dai to buy and burn MKR or pay for dev support to accelerate protocol improvements. The post also addresses concerns about the Dai price crashing and suggests limiting the amount of unbacked Dai printed. The proposal aims to have a smooth rate of MKR burn and avoid risks and negative PR of taking on massive amounts of USDC to fix the peg.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: They’re not Afraid of unbacked and uninspected food like Sushi and Yams  so, ya–what’s the deal Maker Community? Where’s the European Food Safety Authority when you need them?
GPT-discussion-categories: None of the topics listed match.

content.content: I wanted this as one of many monetary tools in the hopper for a long time. I can only speculate based on discussion I have seen around this and the proposals that are stuck (MIP20 vox) and the like. I think the 1:1 DAI to collateral backing value is considered one ot the key Maker value components and a large portion of the community is unwilling to give on this value particularly to manage the PEG.  The reason I pointed this out as an option was the observation that during BT the protocol ran with an approximately 1DAI to .93 collateral value with the PEG trading at like 1.02 for a week.  The market believed the hole would be filled and DAI liquidity was scare so it traded above 1 and continued to do so even after the hole was filled.    My thought was that we needed to try to just mint 1M unbacked DAI (1% of float at the time) and see if the markets even flinch.  If they would then we have a lever, if they don’t - we don’t. The community was almost unanimously against doing anything like this with comments that doing it would break trust in Maker with DAI users/holders. I consider the 1:1 DAI collateral backing to be almost a #1 priority for the community.  This taking full priority to a PEG in 1.01-1.02 range for months now.   The second priority appears to be a general loathing of taking on substantial stablecoins to help manage the PEG and a concern over centralization of risk into stablecoins for DAI generation/value.   Once you have these two constraints there isn’t much room left for PEG management other than onboarding some large borrowers/asset players like RWA and trying to grow this system hoping growth will solve the PEG problem. While I think this will help I grow more sure we need additional DAI liquidity levers but I can only speak from an observational perspective.   So far 1:1 backing of DAI is priority #1 in a great majority of the community and I think for good reason(s).
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
None of the topics listed match
None of the topics listed match

content.content: Great point - that we did have unbacked dai for a long time after BT and it didn’t impact Dai price in part because people knew we could fill the whole.  Agree with you that 1:1 backing seems to be popular but its also naive and takes away the best lever of peg management.  Why do so many people support it?  Its really holding the protocol back and making it more likely that Dai becomes irrelevant.   I think RWA are fine but its going to violate what I consider to be the most value aspect of Dai - on chain transparency and decentralization.  Once we have RWA, no one can verify the backing on chain any more.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal
None of the topics listed match
None of the topics listed match

content.content: latetot:  Agree with you that 1:1 backing seems to be popular but its also naive and takes away the best lever of peg management. Why do so many people support it?   Others will have to speak on this.  It was just my observation that breaking the 1:1 DAI collateral backing value to be something the vast majority involved here and in governance rejects. BTW:   We already have variations of RWA with ‘some’ verification transparency.   The quesiton becomes do you believe the verifiers fiducial responsiblities in this regard.   I will say one thing IF these protocols only limit themselves to stablecoins and crypto assets we will never get robust markets or real growth.   Quite literally crypto needs to take on some Real World Risk to make the next growth phase.   I also agree it won’t be without some pain in the road but I think the risks are worth the rewards.   I want to see crypto value grow to over $1T into the $10T range and the only way I see this happening is with RWA in this space.

content.content: This is what happens when ideologists have control. There is no room for evolution.
So you support having some reasonable amount of unbacked dai?

Aaron_Bartsch:  This is what happens when ideologists have control. There is no room for evolution.   Well I just happened to note how strongly the community rejected this.   I saw people on different sides of other issues be unified on this one issue.   This tells me this isn’t just a signular ideological view but a combination of beliefs and views leading to a general community choice not to give on this. My point was that ‘as an experiment’ it could be tried and reversed out very easily.   I was thinking about it like a jab at the markets to see if they would even react at all that is easily reversed.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: There was a poll on the subject [Poll] Should MakerDAO print unbacked DAI to solve the peg issue? . Probably some argument there. Having USDC-A 101% LR  or QE is strictly superior to unbacked DAI (if you think USDC is a bit better than nothing) and it’s not that of a consensus (break even currently).

content.content: I think experimenting with different solutions is important and just hand waving an idea away because it doesn’t conform to how you “believe” the system should work will be the death of said system. If you can’t pivot quickly based on new information you’re gonna have a bad time.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: I support 101%LR but I think unbacked Dai could complement this and reduce the amount of USDC protocol has to hold.   I wonder whether views have changed as the crisis has worsened and people see the problems of the other solutions.  Also- I wonder if views would change if people knew the unbacked Dai would be used to buy and burn MKR directly.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: latetot:  So you support having some reasonable amount of unbacked dai?   Conceptually I have advocated for a secondary surplus that if one connected the DAI minted for it to the value of the assets in it (i.e. accessible by DAI during an ES) this would retain a 1:1 backing between the combined systems (primary collateral + primary DAI + secondary collatera + secondary minted DAI) where the key component to this is during ES governance could NOT connect the secondary surplus collateral to the secondary surplus DAI minted to buy that collateral.  In this way one breaks the 1:1 backing value on the primary system while keeping it in the sum of the primary and secondary. The secondary being a secondary surplus where DAI is minted by the primary system to buy assets to stick into the secondary providing DAI liquidity into markets but keeping this extra DAI backed only in the secondary surplus reserve and governance being in control of whether or not to connect the collateral in the secondary surplus to the outstanding DAI during an ES to re-establish 1:1 backing value or not. This was a way to create a tilt off 1:1 backing in the primary system while still retaining a protocol 1;1 backing generally.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
None

content.content: SebVentures:  Having USDC-A 101% LR or QE is strictly superior to unbacked DAI (if you think USDC is a bit better than nothing) and it’s not that of a consensus (break even currently).   I am rapidly coming to the view that first upping the DC on the USDC to 100-150M and then putting LR to say 1.02 and system taking on 100-200M USDC is not unreasonable here.  Particularly in light of RWA coming on line and wanting to convert DAI to USD in significant chunks.     Aaron_Bartsch:  I think experimenting with different solutions is important and just hand waving an idea away because it doesn’t conform to how you “believe” the system should work will be the death of said system. If you can’t pivot quickly based on new information you’re gonna have a bad time.   As one with now 30 years of varying operational experience I am a person that considers and weighs all options no matter how I feel about them.   I am swayed by good argument particularly with data supporting it.   I also am big on doing experiments particularly if it can be shown no permanent damage would be done to anything when done and a good amount of data will be provided to make a choice of some kind.  I come to learn while I have predicted ‘hard times’ for organizations and seen them come to pass, some so bad they killed a business entirely, for the most part businesses and operations muddle through even if they have a ‘bad time’.

content.content: Make an effort to use the categories and tags provided, please.

Having unbacked DAI would essentially turn the token into magic internet money with no intrinsic value. At least now, DAI has as much intrinsic value as the collateral (which ironically may be nothing in the case of some collateral types).
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: For me, it’s unclear what “unbacked Dai” actually means?

It means that there would be Dai outstanding that did not have a specific CDP asset backing it.  The effect would be that at the time of an emergency shutdown and assuming that MKR was worthless, each Dai outstanding would have a claim to less than $1 in collateral.
If the protocol minted Dai to purchase USDC, would that be considered “unbacked”? Sorry I am just trying to understand what you mean.

No- with USDC, you can assume price stability so it would stay backed (but with the risk of having massive amounts of stablecoins in the vaults that could default) .  But if you minted Dai to buy ETH or MKR and it turned of vault liquidations and the value fell below the amount of outstanding Dai, you would have unbacked Dai.   The advantage would be that even though you might have Dai backed by 0.99 worth of collateral, the collateral pool could remain fully decentralized.  When the peg was restored, you could make the vaults whole again with SF income.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: latetot:  It means that there would be Dai outstanding that did not have a specific CDP asset backing it   Why “afraid”? Probably this is the reason. You are redefining Dai. I mean, yes, we can do it. But probably this should be advertised to the whole defi ecosystem, before you actually do it.

content.content: Fine but keep in mind people are happy to pay $1.01 for a Dai that is backed by $1.00 of collateral.   Why is this so different than people paying $1.00 for a Dai that is backed by $0.99 in collateral?  I support current use of USDC vaults to fix peg, but don’t kid yourself that this strategy doesnt have significant risks and negative publicity associated with it.  Printing unbacked Dai is only other alternative to centralized stablecoins to fix peg and keeps protocol more decentralized and unique.  If limited to 1% of outstanding supply, would be powerful way to restore peg with completely manageable risk.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: I believe it is hard to limit to a fixed percent, and the amount of unbacked dai is likely to grow overtime, especially if the demand never eases up. Like stablecoin backed dai, the solution only temporarily fixes the problem else we have to keep increasing the amount of dai produced.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Its actually fairly simple to limit unbacked Dai to a fixed percent even without any new smart contract code.  It would work like this:  Enable MKR vaults; turn off liquidations, set LR to 1.00. (Amount of unbacked Dai would depend on price of MKR). Set debt ceiling for MKR vaults to 1% of outstanding dai.  Assuming targeting of max 1% of unbacked Dai, this would mean that target would be exceeded only if large drop in MKR price and large contraction in backed Dai supply.  Could set higher buffers if needed.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: I don’t mean that it’s technically difficult to limit it, so much as it may be difficult to unravel the unbacked dai position later. It doesn’t fundamentally fix the demand/supply imbalance unless it is a significant percent of total dai supply. Even if it were a significant percent, we would then probably be stuck with that percent as a constant supply of unbacked dai, since unraveling the position would push the peg back up.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: I wouldn’t say afraid. But it goes against the entire point of the system in the first place. As other have pointed out, it would undermine trust in Maker. Dai, by definition and design, is backed by more than its value in collateral, because if there is an ES and the system defaults, Dai holders are supposed to be able to redeem their Dai for its value in collateral. If the Dai is unbacked, then for this end it is completely worthless. I would rather have the entire system backed by a single, centralized stablecoin than have unbacked Dai, because that still gives the currency intrinsic value (such as it would be). I, for one, don’t particularly care to pay attention to the price of an asset; I care about its underlying value. The difference is, the market can (in theory) make up whatever price it wishes, but an asset’s value is relatively stable, is intrinsic to the asset, and therefore is not assigned by the market–a constant struggle to find the right price for a given value. Look at the DotCom bubble–Internet companies during this period were experiencing phenomenal growth in price, but the bubble collapsed because the price did not match the underlying value of the assets in question, and the market corrected itself (much to the detriment of speculators). This can go the other way, too; an asset can be priced under its value, and when this happens great gains can be made. Tl;dr I don’t care about the peg, not in particular. I don’t care what Dai is trading at on the market. I care about the value behind the Dai, and unbacked Dai by definition has no value behind it. This, I think, is the real reason why so many people are against it. It’s speculating versus investing.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
None of the topics listed match
None of the topics listed match

content.content: Keep in mind though that if you had 1% of Dai unbacked, it would simply mean that each Dai is backed by $0.99 worth of collateral in the case of ES.  Its not that some dai is backed by $1 and some dai has $0 backing.  To the extent people care about value backing, this is just a way to lower the price to the peg other than accumulating massive amounts of centralized stablecoins.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: For sure, but in such a case, if unbacked Dai exists and assuming 100% of Dai is free to move (i.e., there isn’t a portion in an address the keys to which have been lost) someone is going to be left holding worthless Dai, and no one wants that.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: the way the code works is that if there was an imbalance between dai outstanding and value of collateral at the time of an ES, all dai would be able to claim the same reduced amount in ES.  Every Dai holder would get $0.99 worth of collateral in an ES in my example.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: I see. This was a misunderstanding on my part, my apologies.
No need to apologize . Most people seem to share your overall view that unbacked Dai is too large a violation of the social contract.

Keep in mind also that dai currently is significantly overcollateralized, at least for non stablecoin assets. Having 1% of dai unbacked would still mean dai is backed by >$1 of collateral, my understanding is this would simply decrease the overcollateralization of the dai pool. If you included stablecoin assets I’m not sure what the current collateralization ratio is, but that would be an interesting figure to know.
